description: Elevator control systems and group dispatching

questions.question: What is the function of an elevator controller?
options: To manage all elevator operations including motion, doors, and safety
questions.explanation: The controller is the brain of the elevator, managing motor operation, door control, position sensing, safety circuits, and communication with the dispatch system.

questions.question: What is simplex operation?
questions.explanation: Simplex refers to a single elevator operating independently, not coordinated with other elevators in the building.

questions.question: What is group supervisory control?
options: A system coordinating multiple elevators to efficiently serve hall calls
questions.explanation: Group supervisory systems coordinate multiple elevators, assigning hall calls to the most appropriate car based on algorithms for efficiency.

questions.question: What is a hall call?
options: A passenger request to summon an elevator from a floor landing
questions.explanation: A hall call is registered when a passenger presses the up or down button at a floor landing to summon an elevator.

questions.question: What is a car call?
options: A destination floor selected by a passenger inside the elevator
questions.explanation: A car call is registered when a passenger inside the elevator presses a floor button to select their destination.

questions.question: What is a VFD (Variable Frequency Drive)?
options: A motor controller that varies speed by adjusting electrical frequency
questions.explanation: VFDs control AC motor speed by varying the frequency of the electrical supply, enabling smooth acceleration/deceleration and precise floor leveling.

questions.question: What is independent service mode?
options: Mode where an elevator responds only to car calls, ignoring hall calls
questions.explanation: Independent service allows exclusive use of an elevator (e.g., for moving furniture), responding only to car calls and holding doors until sent to another floor.

questions.question: What is inspection mode?
options: Slow-speed operation controlled from car top for maintenance
questions.explanation: Inspection operation allows slow-speed control from the car top for maintenance and inspection, with safety circuits still active.

questions.question: What is firefighter's service Phase I?
options: Automatic recall of elevators to a designated floor upon fire alarm
questions.explanation: Phase I recall automatically returns elevators to a designated floor (usually lobby) when the building fire alarm activates, for firefighter access.

questions.question: What is firefighter's service Phase II?
options: Manual control of elevator by firefighters using special key
questions.explanation: Phase II allows firefighters to manually control a recalled elevator using a special key, overriding normal automatic operations.

questions.question: What is destination dispatch?
options: Passengers select destination before entering; system assigns elevator
questions.explanation: Destination dispatch has passengers enter their destination floor before boarding. The system groups passengers going to similar floors for efficiency.

questions.question: What is elevator zoning?
options: Assigning elevators to serve specific floor ranges
questions.explanation: Zoning dedicates elevators to specific floor ranges (e.g., low-rise, mid-rise, high-rise zones) in tall buildings for efficiency.

questions.question: What is up-peak mode?
options: Dispatch algorithm for heavy incoming lobby traffic (morning rush)
questions.explanation: Up-peak dispatches elevators to return empty to the lobby during heavy incoming traffic periods (morning arrival) to minimize wait times.

questions.question: What is down-peak mode?
options: Dispatch algorithm for heavy outgoing lobby traffic (evening departure)
questions.explanation: Down-peak dispatches elevators to upper floors during heavy outgoing traffic (evening departure) to minimize passenger wait times.

questions.question: What is the position transducer?
options: A device that tracks the exact position of the elevator car
questions.explanation: Position transducers (encoders, tape readers) continuously track car position for accurate floor leveling and display.

questions.question: What is load weighing in elevators?
options: Measuring car load for dispatching and overload protection
questions.explanation: Load weighing devices measure car load for dispatch decisions (bypass halls when full), overload alarms, and proper motor control.

questions.question: What triggers elevator overload bypass?
options: Load exceeds threshold (typically 80%); car bypasses hall calls
questions.explanation: When the load weighing device indicates the car is near capacity (typically 80%), the elevator bypasses hall calls to efficiently serve existing passengers.

questions.question: What is door dwell time?
options: Time doors remain open at a floor before closing automatically
questions.explanation: Door dwell (hold) time is the adjustable time doors remain open at a floor. It can vary based on traffic, time of day, or floor.

questions.question: What is the door reopening device?
options: Safety device (photoeye or edge) that reopens closing doors if obstructed
questions.explanation: Door reopening devices (photoeyes, safety edges, presence sensors) detect obstructions and reopen closing doors to prevent injury.

questions.question: What is reduced speed door closing (nudging)?
options: Doors close slowly with audible warning after extended open time
questions.explanation: Nudging mode closes doors at reduced speed with an audible warning after doors have been blocked open excessively, to eventually complete the close cycle.

questions.question: What is an encoder in elevator systems?
options: A device measuring motor/sheave rotation for speed and position
questions.explanation: Encoders mounted on the motor or sheave measure rotation to determine car speed and position for the control system.

questions.question: What is a PLC in elevator control?
options: Programmable Logic Controller - a digital computer for automation
questions.explanation: PLCs are industrial computers used in some elevator controllers to process inputs, execute logic, and control outputs for elevator operation.

questions.question: What is the safety chain in elevator controls?
options: Series of safety switch contacts that must all be closed for operation
questions.explanation: The safety chain is a series of safety devices wired in series. If any device opens (trips), the chain breaks and stops the elevator.

questions.question: What is closed-loop vector control?
options: VFD technique using feedback for precise torque and speed control
questions.explanation: Closed-loop vector (flux vector) control uses motor feedback to precisely control torque and speed for smooth ride quality and accurate leveling.

questions.question: What is regenerative braking energy handling?
options: Returning generated energy to the grid or dissipating as heat
questions.explanation: During regenerative braking (overhauling conditions), the motor generates electricity. This can be returned to the grid, shared with other elevators, or dissipated in resistors.

questions.question: What is AI-based elevator dispatching?
options: Using artificial intelligence to optimize dispatch decisions
questions.explanation: AI dispatch systems learn traffic patterns and optimize car assignments to minimize wait times and improve overall building traffic handling.

questions.question: What is a rope gripper (machine-room-less safety)?
options: A device that can stop the car by gripping the ropes in emergencies
questions.explanation: Some MRL elevators use rope grippers as an alternative to traditional car safeties, providing emergency stopping capability by gripping the suspension ropes.

questions.question: What is unintended car movement protection (UCM)?
options: System detecting and stopping movement with doors open at landing
questions.explanation: UCM protection detects unintended car movement (roll-away) when doors are open at a landing and activates a stopping device to prevent injury.

questions.question: What is seismic operation?
options: Automatic shutdown and inspection after seismic event detection
questions.explanation: Seismic controls stop elevators and prevent restart after earthquake detection until inspected for damage, per code requirements.

questions.question: What is remote monitoring for elevators?
options: Real-time monitoring of elevator status and faults from off-site
questions.explanation: Remote monitoring systems transmit elevator status, faults, and operating data to service providers for proactive maintenance and faster response.

questions.question: What is elevator traffic analysis?
options: Studying usage patterns to optimize dispatch and plan capacity
questions.explanation: Traffic analysis studies passenger flow, wait times, and elevator utilization to optimize settings and assess whether capacity meets demand.

questions.question: What is the door zone?
options: The range around a floor level where doors are permitted to open
questions.explanation: The door zone is the limited range (typically Â±3-4 inches) around the floor level where car and hoistway doors are permitted to open.

questions.question: What is pre-opening of doors?
options: Opening doors before arrival at floor level
Opening car doors as car approaches floor while still moving slowly
questions.explanation: Some systems begin opening car doors as the car approaches the floor at reduced speed (within door zone), improving passenger throughput.

questions.question: What is hall call timeout?
options: Automatic cancellation of unanswered hall calls after set time
questions.explanation: Hall calls that aren't answered within a set time (typically 45-90 seconds) are cancelled and re-registered to allow reassignment.

questions.question: What is sector dispatching?
options: Algorithm dividing the building into sectors for elevator assignment
questions.explanation: Sector dispatching divides floors into sectors, assigning each elevator responsibility for certain sectors to reduce stops and improve efficiency.
